Current verdict at EA release:

The game has all the foundations to excel, and it pays homage to a blend between gameplay loops, systems and visuals/atmospherics that you'd associate with Breath of the wild and Valheim. It does a lot of things good and it does some bad. The reason that I've chosen to not recommend it after 9 hrs played is as follows;

It's gameplay loop is centered around combat and progression. But you're far too stuck in the repetitive cycle of having to scavenge every little bit of scraps from enemies and those same respawning enemies over and over, to get anywhere progression wise in terms of stats or tech opportunities. The burden on the player is far too high relative to the feeling of reward you get when you get over that hurdle. Also there are some annoying bugs that they need to fix. But except for that one which doesn't let me damage mobs sometimes, nothing really bothered me that much. The combat is not enjoyable in the long run. And considering how much you have to grind to at least FEEL like you're getting something exciting out of it, you're bound to get burned out from it. As I was. 

If I was allowed to make changes to this game I would reword the combat, OR I would introduce some actual skills into the game that allows the player to express themselves more than spamming left click on whatever weapon you're using when you have the stamina for it (an annoying and tedious resource in this game). I would also rework the loot system. I find my self not giving a shit about chests. I have to subject myself to way too much combat for the resources I need to craft gear (for example fabric and other "pelts"), which is quite frustrating with this combat system.

Level design, music/visuals, quests all good. It's just that you never end up feeling rewarded really. The player has little to no creative expression in combat except abusing bugs or getting pegged by them. And the loot is very irrelevant except for advancing crafting/tech. Stats are uninteresting and prove very little variation, if any, in contemporary loot tiers. Just having inventory weight makes this experience 10x more tedious as well. Bed doesn't let you sleep through the night ffs. 

Felt like I was getting cucked out a good fantasy RPG experience really. Sad to see, and I hope the devs turn it around so I actually want to play this again some day.

Edit: For context, this is the type of game I would like to love. In these days where dark fantasy prevails, I miss the old high fantasy games and settings in any genre. I love them like you would not believe. And considering that in the open world survival crafting genre (a genre I also love), there is a DISMAL lack of any ambitious fantasy game (and I believe that there is a good untapped market for it), it's just another disappointment to be honest. I am still waiting for what this game wants to be. 

Also, it does have skills, but it's scarce, and it takes forever to get them. Another thing I'd like to mention in regards to this review, is that it's a singleplayer frame of reference. As such, the grinding issues are probably a result of the game not being balanced for solo play, which I believe should be the baseline for any game. And thus scale it up.

Frozen Flame is a survival adventure sandbox game a la Valheim set in the vibrant (if slightly generic) world of Arcana, an ancient land steeped in magic both good and evil. For you see, Arcana has been beset by the Faceless—a mysterious evil entity who has spread a nondescript curse across the land and, you guessed it, you're the only one who can stop it. If this premise sounds familiar, that’s because it is, but it’s not why you’re really here, is it? No, you’re here to say “forget the Faceless,” I want to build cool houses, cook cool meals, kill cool bosses, and just generally lose myself in a fun fantasy world, maybe with a friend or two. And if this is indeed what you're looking for in a game, congratulations! You have pretty much found it. Because Frozen Flame checks all of the boxes that fans of the survival adventure sandbox genre have come to love and expect. 

For example, there’s a fairly robust building mode that allows you to create the fantasy home of your dreams. Or, if you’re like me and lack any semblance of architectural prowess, the tiny prison cottage of your nightmares. There’s also a decently deep crafting system that allows you to (after gathering all the requisite resources scattered about the world) hit all the fantasy crafting highlights: armor, weapons, makeshift shelter, you name it. And finally, Frozen Flame invites you to get experimental in the kitchen—or bonfire, rather—as no two ingredients will produce anything short of an edible, health-restoring meal, with some perks thrown in for flavor. 

So, after gearing up and grabbing an NPC quest or two, it’s time to hit the road and see what Arcana has to offer. There are time trials to complete, collectables to collect, jumping puzzles to jump, and vistas to... vist. Occasionally, you’ll stumble upon the game’s narrator—a fairly forgettable “you are our last hope” kind of lady that appears as a white raven—and she’ll bestow you with unsolicited lore about the land. 

And all that (the cooking, crafting, building, and aimless exploration) is about it as far as what I would call Frozen Flame’s strengths. So, if you've been sitting there muttering to yourself, “Just hurry up and tell me what there is to kill and how to kill it,” I’m afraid I have some bad news: at least at this stage in Early Access, Frozen Flame’s combat is a bit shit. There’s no optional target lock a la Dark Souls, so many of your attacks and abilities will either stop well short or sail right past the enemy. If you do happen to land a blow, the actual attack animations and associated sounds don’t combine to create anything particularly impactful. It’s also easy to cheese some of the bosses, as they won’t always aggro you if you stand just outside the zone of the fight. If you do manage to catch one's attention, contrary to what I thought for the first several hours of playing this game, there is a dodge but you wouldn’t know it if you’re playing on gamepad, as the controls aren’t re-mappable, and nothing seems to be the dodge button by default.
